clips.what_happens_visually: Kevin says "probably when I ran over him the first time", shrugs, smiles, and looks at the camera.
clips.dialogue_hook: Probably when I ran over him the first time.
clips.meme_caption:
Oops, I shipped a bug
to prod again
clips.why_it_works: The casual delivery of a disastrous confession makes it relatable to engineers who accidentally push bugs to production.

clips.what_happens_visually: Jim and Pam are sitting side by side. Jim says "But watch this guy make a billion dollars off my idea". Pam looks at Jim with a concerned expression.
clips.dialogue_hook: But watch this guy make a billion dollars off my idea.
clips.meme_caption:
Watching your ex-colleague
launch your side project
clips.why_it_works: The regretful tone and the visual of Pam's concern makes it relatable to founders who see others succeed with their ideas.

clips.what_happens_visually: Kelly Kapoor is carrying a pile of coats and says "I'm going to Miami beaches to hang with Lebron James and Gloria Estefan".
clips.dialogue_hook: I'm going to Miami beaches to hang with Lebron James and Gloria Estefan.
clips.meme_caption:
Me after quitting my job
to 'build in public'
clips.why_it_works: The absurdly aspirational statement contrasts with the reality of most early-stage founders, creating humor.

clips.what_happens_visually: Pam says "Don't you guys have everything? It's just a paper company". Jim adjusts his tie.
clips.dialogue_hook: Don't you guys have everything? It's just a paper company.
clips.meme_caption:
"Why are you still working
on that side project?"
clips.why_it_works: The contrast between the question and the visual of Jim's discomfort highlights the often-unspoken pressure to justify ambition.

clips.what_happens_visually: Michael Scott is trying to sell call cards and says "That's a nice attitude Ryan, I'm helping you invest in your future my friend".
clips.dialogue_hook: I'm helping you invest in your future my friend.
clips.meme_caption:
Recruiters be like:
'It's a great opportunity!'
clips.why_it_works: The overly enthusiastic and ultimately self-serving statement mirrors the often-exaggerated promises of recruiters.

clips.what_happens_visually: Michael Scott says "You know what Toby, when the son of the deposed King of Nigeria emails you directly asking for help, you help!".
clips.dialogue_hook: When the son of the deposed King of Nigeria emails you directly asking for help, you help!
clips.meme_caption:
Me explaining why I'm
building a blockchain app
clips.why_it_works: The absurdly illogical justification resonates with the often-tenuous rationales behind certain tech trends.

clips.what_happens_visually: Ryan says "Smokey's dead". Pam asks "Smokey the bear?" Ryan says "Smokey Robinson, Pam."
clips.dialogue_hook:
Smokey's dead.
Smokey the bear?
Smokey Robinson, Pam.
clips.meme_caption:
When you tell your boss
about a tech legend
clips.why_it_works: The generational disconnect and the visual of Pam's confusion highlights the gap in knowledge about tech history.

clips.what_happens_visually: Dwight is sitting on a fitness ball and falls off it.
clips.meme_caption:
Me trying to use
Cursor AI
clips.why_it_works: The physical comedy of falling off the ball visualizes the frustration of trying to use a new, unstable AI tool.
